document.masterDocTitle: Redescription of Bomis larvata L. Koch, 1874 with the description of a new Australian species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Redescription of Bomis larvata L. Koch, 1874 with the description of a new Australian species

subSubSection.paragraph: Etymology. Hippop - refers to a hippopotamus-like shape of the clypeus. The word hippopotamus is derived from Greek. The suffix -onoi is established as a tribute to the Japanese arachnologist Hirotsugu Ono, one of the world most prominent arachnologists specializing in the taxonomy of Thomisidae .

Diagnosis . Anterior margin of clypeus straight ( Figs 36 , 39–40 ) with dense strobiliform and spinose setae ( Fig. 42 ). Venter of opisthosoma with one semi-circular apodeme in the middle and two pairs of small triangular apodemes on the ( Fig. 45 ). Epigyne 1.5 to 2 times wider than long with two protruding conical protuberances situated close to each other ( Figs 33 , 37 , 46 ); epigynal orifices directed posteriorly on top of two conical protuberances ( Fig. 46 ). Male palp with slightly curved bean-shape tegulum ( Figs 48 , 53 ); embolus one quarter the length of tegulum ( Figs 48 , 53–54 ) and protuberance on cymbial depression with plumose and bacilliform hairless setae situated in apical-cymbial depression ( Fig. 54 ); cymbial retrolateral margin without notch.

Length of leg segments in females of
Bomis hippoponoi
sp. nov.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 29–34.
Bomis hippoponoi
, female and male. 29–30 habitus of holotype (29 dorsal, 30 frontal); 31 different pattern of habitus of female, dorsal; 32 habitus of male, dorsal; 33 epigyne, ventral; 34 vulva, dorsal. Scale bars: (29–31) = 0.5 mm; (32) = 0.4 mm; (33, 34) = 0.05 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Male: Body length: 1.38–1.7 (mean 1.57, SD±0.12, n=15), prosoma length: 0.75–1.44 (mean 0.9, SD ±0.16, n=15), prosoma width: 0.72–0.92 (mean 0.85, SD±0.05, n=15), prosoma height: 0.48–0.72 (mean 0.59, SD±0.06, n=15), prosoma length/width ratio: mean 1.06 (n=15), opisthosoma length: 0.82–1.25 (mean 1.12, SD±0.14, n=15), opisthosoma width: 1.1–1.48 (mean 1.31, SD±0.12, n=15), opisthosoma height: 0.6–1 (mean 0.77, SD±0.13, n=15), opisthosoma length/width ratio: mean 0.85 (n=15). The prosoma is as wide as long ( Figs 32 , 47 ), and is covered by numerous tubercles and rounded small cavities ( Fig. 50 ). The clypeus is 0.35 long with the ratio of its length to AME-AME distance being 2.0, the ventral margin is straight ( Figs 50–51 ) with numerous marginal strobiliform setae ( Fig. 51 ). All eyes and eye tubercles are small, ALE, PLE and PME tubercles of equal size, the x/ y ratio of 0.77, the diameter of lenses AME>ALE=PLE>PME, the size of eye tubercles ALE=PLE ≈ PME>AME. The legs have rugose surfaces covered by various types of setae, the most diverse on the tibiae (plain spiniform, spinose, robust ensiform with truncated tip, plumose with clavate shape) ( Fig. 52 ), two or three trichobothria are found on each tibia dorsally on the proximal end and one trichobothrium on each metatarsus on the dorsal side, the leg formula follows the pattern of I=II-III=IV. Embolus is short, one quarter the length of the tegulum ( Figs 48 , 53– 54 ). Cymbial depression with protuberance supplied by several hairy setae and one hairless, baciliform seta with circularly twisted furrows (groves) ( Fig. 54 ), on top of the cymbium there are numerous setae similar to the ventral cymbial protuberance ( Fig. 54 ). The palpal tibia has no apophyses ( Figs 48–49 , 53, 55 ), but four types of setae retrolaterally (baciliform, setiform, spiniform, clavate; all spinose) ( Figs 49 , 55 ). The other parts of the body and appendages correspond to the female description.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 35–38.
Bomis hippoponoi
, female. 35 habitus, dorsal; 36 prosoma, frontal; 37 epigyne, ventral; 38 vulva, dorsal. Scale bars: (35, 36) = 1 mm; (37, 38) = 0.1 mm.

FIGURES 39–44.
Bomis hippoponoi
, female, SEM photos. 39 prosoma, frontal; 40 clypeus and chelicerae; 41 clypeus, surface of integument; 42 setae on margin of clypeus; 43 sternum, posterior; 44 opisthosoma, dorsum, anterior. PaR1-Pa1—width of marginal strobiliform seta (mss) (=5.684 µm). Scale bars: (39, 40) = 0.1 mm; (41, 43) 0.02 mm; (42) = 0.01 mm; (44) = 0.2 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph: Distribution. The species has been recorded most frequently in Southern Australia . It was also collected in Queensland and in New South Wales (Lord Howe Island).
Habitat preferences. The species inhabits mainly shrubs, dense undergrowth and reeds. It is found in woodlands, gardens, on coastal cliffs and in sand dunes.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURES 45–46.
Bomis hippoponoi
, female, SEM photos. 45 opisthosoma, venter, anterior; 46 epigyne, ventral. Scale bars: (45, 46) = 0.1 mm.

FIGURES 47–49.
Bomis hippoponoi
, male. 47 habitus, dorsal; 48–49 left pedipalp (48 ventral, 49 retrolateral). Scale bars: (47) = 1 mm; (48, 49) = 0.1 mm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Remarks on identification. Though it is difficult to distinguish these two species in the field due to their small dimensions, the slightly divergent patterns on a female dorsal part of the abdomen is a good feature for the initial identification. The white transverse stripe is situated anteriorly to the intermediate pair of apodemes in females of
B. hippoponoi
but posteriorly in
B. larvata
. The two species are easily identified when the diagnostic features are analyzed with optical equipment. Also the ratio of the sternum’s width to the width of its posterior part (SWR) is slightly different. Mean SWR for
B. larvata
was 2.31 and for
B. hippoponoi
2.24 ( Fig. 56 ). However, there is a zone of overlap, and the discriminant analysis did not separate the data set into two groups (Wilks' Lambda=0.95, F=2.51, p=0.11).
